prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Sensitivity requirement: Judeging from our ALMA Cycle 0 data, we request a sensitivity of 5 mJy/beam (1 sigma) with a velocity resolution of 0.5 km s-1 for the DNC emission at 228.9 GHz. The other observed molecular line emission, except for N2D+, are thought to be stronger than the DNC emission.
Imaging requirement: Since we focus on the fragmentation of the dense part in the clumps, the extended emission is not so important for our main purpose. Without the ACA, we can cover the structure with a size of 6". Since the source size is about 12", it is enough to investigate the core distribution within the deep inside of the clump. In addition, we plan to get the zero baseline data with the ASTE telescope. Therefore, we decide not to use the ACA. The angular resolution of 0.2" is necessary in order to investigate the thermal fragmentation process in the clumps, as described in the science justification.
Correlator setup: Since the velocity width is about 2 km s-1, we need a velocity resolution of 0.5 km s-1. Then, we choose the frequency resolution of 244.141 kHz (0.32 km/s) and the bandwidth of 234.375 MHz (307 km/s). In order to reduce the data rate, we select the fraction of "1/2". The observed lines are as follows:DNC, N2D+ (cold dense gas tracer), CS (shock tracer), and CH3OH (shock tracer). At the same time, some hot core tracers, such as HCOOOCH3 and CH3OCH3, can be also observed.
Calibration: we do not need any special calibration, including bandpass accuracy.
Scheduling/time constraints: We have no constraints.
Data rate: According to the OT, the data rate is below the limit.

Sensitivity requirement: Judging from our ALMA Cycle 0 data, we request a sensitivity of 5 mJy/beam (1 sigma) with a velocity resolution of 0.5 km s-1 for the HN13C emission at 261.2 GHz. The other observed molecular lines are thought to be stronger than the HN13C emission.
Imaging requirement: Since we focus on the fragmentation of the dense part in the clumps, the extended emission is not so important for our main purpose. Without the ACA, we can cover the structure with a size of 6". Since the source size is about 12", it is enough to investigate the core distribution within the deep inside of the clump. In addition, we plan to get the zero baseline data with the ASTE telescope. Therefore, we decide not to use the ACA. The angular resolution of 0.2" is necessary in order to investigate the thermal fragmentation process in the clumps, as described in the science justification.
Correlator setup: Since the velocity width is about 2 km s-1, we need the velocity resolution of 0.5 km s-1. Then, we choose the frequency resolution of 244.141 kHz (0.28 km/s) and the bandwidth of 234.375 MHz (269 km/s). In order to reduce the data rate, we select the fraction of "1/2". The observed lines are as follows:HN13C, H13CO+ (dense gas tracer), H13CN (dense gas tracer), and SiO (shock tracer). At the same time, some hot core tracers, such as HCOOOCH3 and CH3OCH3, can be also observed.
Calibration: we do not need any special calibration, including bandpass accuracy.
Scheduling/time constraints: We have no constraints.
Data rate: According to the OT, the data rate is below the limit.

Sensitivity requirement: Judging from our ALMA Cycle 0 data, we request a sensitivity of 10 mJy/beam (1 sigma) with a velocity resolution of 0.5 km s-1 for the N2H+ emission at 279.4 GHz. The N2H+ emission is thought to be stronger than the DNC and HN13C emission.
Imaging requirement: Since we focus on the fragmentation of the dense part in the clumps, the extended emission is not so important for our main purpose. Without the ACA, we can cover the structure with a size of 6". Since the source size is about 12", it is enough to investigate the core distribution within the deep inside of the clump. In addition, we plan to get the zero baseline data with the ASTE telescope. Therefore, we decide not to use the ACA. The angular resolution of 0.2" is necessary in order to investigate the thermal fragmentation process in the clumps, as described in the science justification.
Correlator setup: Since the velocity width is about 2 km s-1, we need the velocity resolution of 0.5 km s-1. Then, we choose the frequency resolution of 244.141 kHz (0.32 km/s) and the bandwidth of 234.375 MHz (307 km/s). In order to reduce the data rate, we select the fraction of "1/2". The observed lines are as follows:N2H+ (cold dense gas tracer), CH3CN (hot core tracer), DCN (dense gas tracer), and H2CO (hot core tracer?).
Calibration: we do not need any special calibration, including bandpass accuracy.
Scheduling/time constraints: We have no constraints.

Sensitivity requirement: Judging from our ALMA Cycle 0 data, we request a sensitivity of 5 mJy/beam (1 sigma) with a velocity resolution of 0.5 km s-1 for the DNC emission at 228.9 GHz. The other observed molecular lines, except for N2D+, are thought to be stronger than the DNC emission.
Imaging requirement: Since we focus on the fragmentation of the dense part in the clumps, the extended emission is not so important for our main purpose. Without the ACA, we can cover the structure with a size of 6". Since the source size is about 15", it is enough to investigate the core distribution within the deep inside of the clump. In addition, we plan to get the zero baseline data with the ASTE telescope. Therefore, we decide not to use the ACA. Scheduling/time constraints: We have no constraints.
Data rate: According to the OT, the data rate is below the limit.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: To investigate star formation in massive clumps, it is essential to reveal the initial physical state of massive clumps. For this purpose, we propose to observe high-mass protostellar objects (HMPOs) in the DNC, HN13C, N2H+ and several molecular lines with high-angular resolution (0.2"). In this program, we examine the diversity of the initial conditions of high-mass star formation. From our single-dish observations, we have found a diversity of the DNC/HNC ratio among the HMPOs. The diversity is not explained by the difference in the "current" temperature. When we consider the time dependence of the deuterium fractionation, the DNC/HNC ratio of the HMPOs is likely to reflect that of their starless phase. If so, it is possible that the diversity is originated from the difference in the duration time of the "cold" (<20 K) starless phase. The duration time of the cold starless phase may affect the fragmentation process in the clumps. To examine this, we would like to compare the core mass distribution between the 2 HMPOs, I18089-1732 MM1 and I18264-1152 MM1. Furthermore, we would like to investigate the history of the fragmentation in the massive clumps from the DNC/HNC ratio.
